title: Address concerns of RGLC 1
body: Address the concerns of Martin Thomson and Rich Salz (but for the ones already addressed by Cas).

title: Sig() could actually be a MAC
body:
Hi folks, thanks for the hard work on this draft! One quick comment:

It seems unnecessary to specify a dieterministic *signature* in the construction of `G'`. Wouldn't a MAC be just as good, much more efficient, and far easier to implement? (In particular, it seems to me that the existing security analysis would apply almost seamlessly to any secure MAC.)

I recognize that using a MAC may be at odds with the HSM use-case, but it seems almost certain that this draft is useful in many settings where an HSM is unavailable. Moreover, since there are effectively no interoperability concerns, it seems like generalizing to allow the more efficient construction is a strict win.

I'm happy to submit a PR clarifying this, if you'd like.

title: Version 1.1 of the security-analysis paper
body:
Added Appendix A with wrapper experiments.
Removed the redundant game (Game 1) from the proof.
Clarified security properties of KDF (kdf security and uniformness preserving), modified the proof.
Considered two cases of using HKDF-extract (direct and reverse orders of arguments)

title: Build on Stanislav's edits, and address Cas' feedback.
Address issues 1,2a,2b,3 from the email thread
body:
Addressing the following issues:
1) Add the issue with weak (or broken) initial entropy source seeding the CSPRNG as additional motivation.
2) Refine the security considerations related to 
a) the usage of Sig - to explicitly address the issue with desired secrecy of Sig(sk, tag1).
b) tag1 - to address the issue with cloning VMs more explicitly.
3) Think about better wordings about the end construction. Personally, I like David's idea of defining this as something like CSPRNG G'.

title: Better wordings about defining the construction
body: Defining the new construction as something like CSPRNG G'.

body: Refine the security considerations related to the usage of Sig - to explicitly address the issue with desired secrecy of Sig(sk, tag1).

body: Add the issue with weak (or broken) initial entropy source seeding the CSPRNG as additional motivation.

Consider running separate DRBG and XORing with G(x)
body: Maybe we can list this as an alternative design for now.

title: Recommend generating a key pair specifically for the purpose of seeding randomness
Do not consume more entropy of G(x) than needed
body: Choose G(x) output size to be minimize of requested and PRF output size

title: Be precise in tag construction, and give specific recommendations
Consider restricting signature computation on tag1 to the RNG generation client, and no others
body: This prevents an attack scenario where an adversary who can observe Sig(k, tag1) uses it as a valid signature of tag1 elsewhere.

title: Clarify what parts of the protocol are implemented within a HSM, and which are implemented outside
Be consistent with use of "randomness," "random bytes," and "entropy"
body: OpenSSL uses "entropy" as a bitstream to feed into its CSPRNG, and what you get out is "random bytes."  We use the word "randomness" rather than say thing like "a measure of the entropy in the bytes."

title: Clean up use of RNG, PRNG, and CSPRNG.
Split parameters to the KDF
body:
It would be best practice to treat G(x) as a salt for input to HKDF-Extract.

Separately, I noticed that this exposes a problem that you might consider separately: HKDF-Extract produces an output that is the same size as the underlying hash output.  Your text assumes that both the PRF and the KDF produce an output of size L.  That's not necessarily the case, even for HKDF, since HKDF produces output of arbitrary size.

Rather than try to address that, I would recommend that you use HKDF more directly unless there is any reason that you need to maintain flexibility.

title: Generate fixed using a KDF
body:
"I don’t like that the tag is up to the implementation to generate. You end up signing arbitrary data, where the signature could be reused elsewhere. Better to derive a key via a KDF and a unique but exact tag specified in the standard."

https://twitter.com/rootlabs/status/975216701468889088

title: Go POC.
Wrapping interface does not match the interface for a PRNG.
body:
The current construction works like so:

   PRF(KDF(G(x) || H(Sig(sk, tag1))), tag2)

This works fine if |x| is equal to the PRF output size. If it's more (or less), then it becomes somewhat of a pain to use this interface as a direct replacement for the PRNG. What if we modified this slightly as follows:

  key = KDF(G(x) || Sig(sk, tag1))
  nonce = tag2 // incremented each time
  output = AES-CTR(key, nonce, 0^|x|)

Or, alternatively:

  key = KDF(Sig(sk, tag1))
  nonce = tag2 // incremented each time
  output = AES-CTR(key, nonce, G(x))

title: Include PoC Go reference implementation
Updates, once more.
Caw/edits
Caw/edits
Updates from Stanislaw's comments
body:
1. First of all, it seems important to state explicitly that such
measures as relying on feeding private keys (or signatures created with
them) to PRNGs can be considered as “last line of defense” only, for
cases when no other entropy sources are available at all.

2. Secondly, since DSA/ECDSA/EC-RDSA signatures require randomness
themselves, it seems reasonable to mention that it would be better to
discuss keys of deterministic signatures (e.g., RSA, if not to consider
PSS) and RSA signatures regarding the provided construction - not
DSA/ECDSA/EC-RDSA. The signature output is not available to anyone, it’s
only fed to a PRF, but anyway the usage of signature schemes requiring
randomness themselves to provide randomness does not seem to be the best
idea.

3. If an equipment is used in a hostile environment, where side-channel
adversaries should be considered, extra operations with private keys must
be taken into account when estimating lifetimes of keys.

4. When a private key is used for such kind of technological signatures,
I’d prefer that the signed data
a. would include timestamps and/or counters
b. would include some data that is specific for a particular device – to
prevent the existence of equivalent PRNGs in different devices dealing
with a single private key (e.g. if one HSM with a server private key is
used from several servers or for the cases of cloned virtual machines).
c. would have some kind of structured form like “This is data signed only
for the purpose of randomness generations (input parameters = [timestamp],
[counter]).” – so these technical signatures can never be used by any
attacker for other purposes (and to prevent all kinds of signing oracle
here) – even despite using them only as PRF inputs.

5. All protocols that exploit this kind of entropy based on long-term
private keys should be analyzed specifically together with a specific
signature scheme, PRF and PRNG – to prevent any influence on security
(e.g. if PRF(KDF(G(x) || Sig(sk, tag)), tag) is used for generation of
random values for ECDSA signatures on the key sk, for the cases when G(x)
degenerates).

Minor changes.
